key-names_key3: Not all `keys` are easy to represent with single text characters. For example, how do you represent SHIFT or the left arrow `key` as a single character? In PyAutoGUI, these `key`board `keys` are represented by short `string` values instead: 'esc' for the ESC `key` or 'enter' for the ENTER `key`.
key-names_key4: Instead of a single `string` argument, a list of these `key`board `key` `strings` can be passed to typewrite(). For example, the following call presses the A `key`, then the B `key`, then the left arrow `key` twice, and finally the X and Y `keys`:
key-names_key5: Because pressing the left arrow `key` moves the `key`board cursor, this will `output` XYab. `Tab`le 18-1 lists the PyAutoGUI `key`board `key` `strings` that you can pass to typewrite() to simulate pressing any combination of `keys`.
key-names_key6: You can also examine the pyautogui.`KEY`BOARD_`KEYS` list to see all possible `key`board `key` `strings` that PyAutoGUI will accept. The 'shift' `string` refers to the left SHIFT `key` and is equivalent to 'shiftleft'. The same applies for 'ctrl', 'alt', and 'win' `strings`; they all refer to the left-side `key`.
key-names_key9: 'a', 'b', 'c', 'A', 'B', 'C', '1', '2', '3', '!', '@', '#', and so on         The `keys` for single characters
key-names_key17: 'pageup', 'pagedown'                                                         The PAGE UP and PAGE DOWN `keys`
key-names_key19: 'up', 'down', 'left', 'right'                                                 The up, down, left, and right arrow `keys`
key-names_key20: 'f1', 'f2', 'f3', and so on                                                 The F1 to F12 `keys`
key-names_key21: 'volumemute', 'volumedown', 'volumeup'                                            The mute, volume down, and volume up `keys` (some `key`boards do not have these `keys`, but your operating system will still be able to understand these simulated `key`presses)
key-names_key23: 'capslock', 'numlock', 'scrolllock'                                            The CAPS LOCK, NUM LOCK, and SCROLL LOCK `keys`
key-names_key26: 'winleft', 'winright'                                                        The left and right WIN `keys` (on Windows)
key-names_key27: 'command'                                                                     The Command () `key` (on OS X) 'option' The OPTION `key` (on OS X)
